document_title: Placenta previa: Classification, symptoms and diagnosis
subsection_content:
Diagnosis is made through ultrasound. Thereby, it is possible to determine which area of ​​the uterus the placenta is attached to, such as the front, back, fundus, body, low attachment, semi-central or central anterior position. (3)
Ultrasound methods are also meaningful in diagnosing placenta previa and complications of placenta accreta. Ultrasound images show that the distance between the placenta and the bladder wall narrows, blood vessels penetrate the uterine muscle wall to the bladder wall on the Doppler ultrasound spectrum. It is often recommended that ultrasound be performed for early detection after the 28th week of pregnancy.
Pregnant women should have regular prenatal checkups to detect pregnancy complications early
